verses.text: Do not quarrel with a powerful man, or you may fall into his hands.
verses.comment: This verse teaches prudence and humility, echoing the wisdom tradition not to provoke those in authority. Comparable advice can be found in Proverbs, emphasizing patience and avoiding unnecessary conflict.

verses.text: Do not contend with a rich man, or you may be swept away by his power.
verses.comment: Wisdom warns against needless disputes with those who have worldly influence. The Old Testament repeatedly counsels just dealings, especially with the rich, whose resources often afford greater leverage.

verses.text: Do not argue with someone who speaks easily; do not heap wood on his fire.
verses.comment: This verse uses a metaphor: adding fuel to an argument only intensifies division. 'Speaking easily' likely refers to those quick with words or prone to quarrel.

verses.text: Do not make fun of someone who repents for a sin; remember that all people are guilty.
verses.comment: Sirach highlights mercy and humility before the reality of universal sin. The link to Psalm 51 reminds us of the call to a contrite heart, fundamental for spiritual growth and reconciliation.

verses.text: Do not reject the teaching of elders, for they have learned from their fathers.
verses.comment: Valuing tradition and wisdom passed down through generations is emphasized here. This verse suggests the importance of respecting apostolic and ecclesial teaching throughout the ages.

verses.text: Do not argue with someone with more learning than you; for you may be shamed, and he will judge you.
verses.comment: Humility in conversations with those of greater wisdom or knowledge is highlighted. Recognizing one's limits leads to true growth and deeper faith.

verses.text: Do not despise someone who has sinned, lest you be ensnared by pride.
verses.comment: Sirach echoes Christ's teaching on mercy and avoiding judgment of others. Emphasis on the spiritual danger of pride, a motif present in both Testaments.

verses.text: Do not dismiss the stories of the ancient sages, but meditate on their words.
verses.comment: Respect for sacred tradition and the wisdom of ages past mirrors the value placed on the continuity of revelation. Learning from history deepens spiritual maturity.

verses.text: Do not ignore the sayings of the elders, for they themselves learned from their ancestors; from them you can acquire understanding and know how to answer in time of need.
verses.comment: Emphasizes generational transmission of wisdom, aligning with the apostolic teaching preserved in the Church. Listening to elders equips us for spiritual and practical challenges.

verses.text: Do not kindle the fire of sinners, lest you be burned by their flames.
verses.comment: Avoid encouragement of evil or participation in sinful conduct. There is a figurative warning for the consequences of associating with habitual transgressors.

verses.text: Do not confront the angry, and do not go with the reckless, lest you be caught in their trap.
verses.comment: The wisdom of distance from hot-tempered and reckless people avoids unnecessary entanglements and dangers. Community discernment is suggested.

verses.text: Do not lend to someone who is stronger than you; if you do lend, count it as lost.
verses.comment: Practical financial wisdom on lending. Christ's advice (Luke 6:35) adds the spiritual dimension of lending in generosity without expecting repayment.

verses.text: Do not guarantee another person’s debt beyond your means; if you do, be ready to pay.
verses.comment: Warns against irresponsible financial guarantees. Old Testament (Proverbs) repeatedly cautions against co-signing for others, promoting prudence.

verses.text: Do not argue with a judge, for judgment belongs to him.
verses.comment: Respects the proper lines of authority in society. Judges represent order and justice, echoing divine judgment in the biblical tradition.

verses.text: Do not travel with someone who is reckless, lest he become burdensome to you; he will do as he pleases and you will suffer for it.
verses.comment: Cautions against the company of those with poor judgment. Proverbs affirms that wise companions lead to wisdom, while fools bring harm.

verses.text: Do not quarrel with someone who is quick-tempered, and do not go into a deserted place with him; for bloodshed may occur when no one is there to help.
verses.comment: Warns against physical and spiritual danger with violent people. Emphasizes personal safety and discernment, linking wisdom to self-preservation.

verses.text: Do not consult with fools, for they cannot keep wise counsel.
verses.comment: Advice on prudent counsel: wisdom is not found in the company of foolish people. The spiritual life calls for discernment in choosing one’s influences.

verses.text: Do not discuss matters before a stranger; you know not what he will do.
verses.comment: Confidentiality and discretion are essential for safety and wisdom. In matters spiritual and temporal, trust must be earned.

verses.text: Do not open your heart to everyone, or you may be repaid with malice.
verses.comment: The final verse urges guardedness and discernment, echoing biblical teaching (Proverbs, Psalms) to protect one’s heart. Spiritual maturity involves knowing when to reveal oneself and when to guard one's soul.
